bestBHT.bht: I have striven the good strife, finished my race, and kept the faith. The fight represents the athletic contest of my struggle for Christ, and the course symbolizes the journey that is now behind me. I have steadfastly maintained the faith of the gospel and lived a life of fidelity to my Master. In my fight, my race, and my faith, I have been a good and faithful soldier to my captain.

Henry Alford: I have striven the good strife...to any contest...specified in the next clause"
I have finished my race...the image belongs peculiarly to St. Paul"
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: I have striven the good strife"; the Greek is not restricted to a fight, but includes any competitive contest, for example, that of the racecourse (1 Timothy 6:12 [ALFORD]; 1 Corinthians 9:24-27; Hebrews 12:1; Hebrews 12:2).
kept the faith—the Christian faith committed to me as a believer and an apostle (compare 2 Timothy 1:14; Revelation 2:10; Revelation 3:10).
Albert Barnes: The Christian life is often represented as a conflict, or warfare;... That noble conflict with sin, the world, the flesh, and the devil, Paul now says he had been able to maintain.
The Christian life, too, is often represented as a 'race' to be run.
I have steadfastly maintained the faith of the gospel; or, have lived a life of fidelity to my Master.
Marvin Vincent: I have fought a good fight." [τον καλον αγωνα ηγωνισμαι]
I have kept the faith." [την πιστιν τετηρηκα]
John Calvin: He even congratulates himself on his death, because it may be regarded as the goal or termination of his course.
To Christ's combatants death is desirable because it puts an end to their labors.
He was a good and faithful soldier to his captain.
Philip Schaff: I have fought the good fight. The Greek is wider in its range, and takes in every kind of contest 'I have striven a good strife' would perhaps be nearer.
I have kept the faith. What had been expressed before figuratively is now stated simply. So far he has not failed; he has kept the faith (in its objective sense) which had been committed to him.
Archibald T. Robertson: I have fought the good fight...The 'fight' is the athletic contest of his struggle for Christ.
I have finished the course...Then the 'course' was ahead of him. Now it is behind him.
I have kept the faith. Paul has not deserted. He has kept faith with Christ.
John Gill: I have fought a good fight...I have finished my course...I have kept the faith."
He desired to finish with joy, and was now finishing...his work was done, and his warfare accomplished.
He had kept pure and incorrupt against all opposition...declaring the whole counsel of God.

bhtAttempts.bht: I have striven the good strife and have finished my race. The 'fight' is the athletic contest of my struggle for Christ. The 'course' was ahead of me, but now it is behind me. I have kept the faith, not deserting, but keeping faith with Christ. The Christian life is often represented as a conflict and a race, a noble struggle with sin and a journey to be completed. I have steadfastly maintained the faith of the gospel and lived a life of fidelity to my Master. In my fight, in my race, and in my faith, I have been a good and faithful soldier to my captain.

I have fought a good fight and finished my course, keeping the faith. The fight represents my struggle for Christ, a noble conflict with sin, the world, and the devil. The course was ahead of me, but now it is behind me. I have steadfastly maintained the faith of the gospel and lived a life of fidelity to my Master. In my fight, in my race, and in my faith, I have been a good and faithful soldier to my captain.

I have striven the good strife, finished my race, and kept the faith. The fight represents the athletic contest of my struggle for Christ, and the course symbolizes the journey that is now behind me. I have steadfastly maintained the faith of the gospel and lived a life of fidelity to my Master. In my fight, my race, and my faith, I have been a good and faithful soldier to my captain.

I have striven the good strife and finished my race, keeping the faith. The fight represents the athletic contest of my struggle for Christ, while the course symbolizes the journey behind me. In my fight, race, and faith, I have been a good and faithful soldier. I have steadfastly maintained the faith of the gospel, living a life of fidelity to my Master.

I have fought a good fight, finished my course, and kept the faith. The fight represents my struggle for Christ, a noble conflict with sin, the world, and the devil. The course was ahead of me, but now it is behind me. I have steadfastly maintained the faith of the gospel and lived a life of fidelity to my Master. In my fight, race, and faith, I have been a good and faithful soldier.
